sentences.sentence_tlingit: Chʼa yóo diyínde i éet x̱ʼawdutaaní, á áwé sh tóox̱ áwé dusnéegun.
sentences.sentence_english: If someone were to talk down to you, one would be offended by it.

sentences.sentence_tlingit: Kʼe wé ax̱ sáni, x̱ʼalitseeni saa áwé yéi yatee wé Weihá, i jeet aawatée.
sentences.sentence_english: My uncle, this is a valuable name, Weihá, [that] he gave to you.

sentences.sentence_tlingit: Yá Yanyeidí Yátxʼix̱ isateeyí dikéexʼ áwé yéi iyatee, i saayí tlax̱ ḵúnáx̱ [x̱ʼalitseen]. Á áwé yéi daayax̱aḵá wé shaawát.
sentences.sentence_english: As [one of] the Children of the Yanyeidí you are exalted; your name is very valuable. This is what I was telling that woman.

sentences.sentence_tlingit: Kʼe yú Queen aadé, ḵa yú King George aadé du yáa ayaduwanéiyi yé, tléil aadé chʼa aadóoch sá chʼa wáa sá has woonax̱siḵaayi yé, tle ḵúnáx̱ yéi áwé yatee wé Yanyeidí Yátxʼi, ḵa wé Yanyeidí, yá Tʼaaḵú kaax̱ áwé.
sentences.sentence_english: As the Queen and King George are respected, so no one will be able to say anything against you; this is truly how it is with the Children of the Yanyeidí and the Yanyeidí, [whose name comes] from the Taku River.

sentences.sentence_tlingit: Á ách áwé ax̱ tuwáa sigóo yisateeí wé aax̱ i shagóon ḵuwdziteeyi yé, yá uháan haa tóonáx̱. Áyá tlax̱ xʼéig̱aa áyá lidzée áyá yeedadi ḵáawu oon yoo x̱ʼadul.átgi.
sentences.sentence_english: Therefore I want you to see the place where your history came into being through us. It is truly difficult to explain this to the younger generation.

sentences.sentence_tlingit: Áyá chʼáakw áyá aag̱áa, chʼul dleit ḵáa ḵoog̱asteejí aag̱áa áwé wooch yáa ayadunéiyin.
sentences.sentence_english: Long ago, before there were white people, then they used to respect one another.

before there were white people,
then
they used to respect one another.

sentences.sentence_tlingit: Haaw, Yéil áwé wa.é, ax̱ sáni saayíx̱ isitee.
sentences.sentence_english: Now, you are a Raven; you are my uncle’s namesake.

lines.line_english: Now, you are a Raven;
you are my uncle’s namesake.

sentences.sentence_tlingit: X̱át áwé G̱ooch yéi x̱at yatee.
sentences.sentence_english: I am a Wolf.

sentences.sentence_tlingit: AAg̱áa áwé wé haa yátxʼi ḵúnáx̱ daatuwtusinéegu aa haa saayí, haa léelkʼw, haa tláakʼw, haa káak.
sentences.sentence_english: And to our children [we give] names [of people] that we held dear: our grandfather, our mother’s sister, our mother’s brother.

sentences.sentence_tlingit: Yéi áwé yáatʼaa saa áwé, x̱ʼadudlitseeni saa áwé, wooch yaag̱áa has ditee hasdu jeex̱ áyá tootee.
sentences.sentence_english: Such names, names we hold dear, are suitable for [our children]; we give them to them.

names we hold dear,

sentences.sentence_english: It’s good that my uncle gave his name to you; there is nothing wrong with it at all, I think.

sentences.sentence_tlingit: X̱wasakóowun tle kʼadéin.

lines.line_english: I knew him well.

sentences.sentence_tlingit: Áyá yeedát chʼu ḵunáa tsu G̱ooch áyá x̱át ha wé ḵáa tsú G̱ooch, chʼa aan áwé chʼu tle wooch x̱ánx̱ ḵaa ludagooḵ. Adáx̱ áwé yoo at kooteek g̱anígún áwé tle yéi x̱at yandusḵéich, «Yá ax̱ aayí ax̱ yádi tsú du yáa saa sá.» Ha wáa sáyú kḵwasáakw?
sentences.sentence_english: But these days, even though, [for example], I am a Wolf, and that man is a Wolf too, they just run to each other anyway. And afterwards, when they have a potlatch, they will say to me, “Me too, give my child a name.” What am I to name her?

and that man is a Wolf too,

sentences.sentence_tlingit: Á áyá ax̱ tugéidex̱ sitee, ḵa yá yeedát aadé yaa at kundayen yé.
sentences.sentence_english: This is wrong to me, and the way things are going these days [is not good].

sentences.sentence_tlingit: Chʼáakw wáa sá aa wuneeyí— tle chʼu shaatkʼátskʼux̱ x̱at sateeyídáx̱ x̱wasakóowun— yá ḵaa eetí daa sá, kʼe ax̱ daa.át sʼéilʼi yáat, chʼa wáa sá óosh x̱at woonee, tle kagax̱ducháak áwé, chʼa ax̱ daḵéisʼi, daa sá tle yéi.
sentences.sentence_english: Long ago, when something would happen to one of them— ever since I was a girl I have known this— whatever a person leaves behind, such as my tattered belongings here, if something were to happen to me, they would pack them up, my sewings or whatever.

lines.line_english: Long ago, when something would happen to one of them—
ever since I was a girl
I have known this—
whatever a person leaves behind,
such as my tattered belongings here,

lines.line_tlingit: chʼa wáa sá óosh x̱at woonee,

they would pack them up,
my sewings
or whatever.

sentences.sentence_tlingit: Tléixʼ táakw shuwuxeexí áwé daak gax̱dul.áat, daaḵw.aa sá G̱oochx̱ siteeyi aa, «I tláakʼw ádi, i tláa ádi,» yóo ḵaa jix̱oox̱ aa kdul.atch tle yóo.
sentences.sentence_english: After one year they would bring them out for those who are of the Wolf clan, “This is your mother’s sister’s; this is your mother’s,” [with these words] they distribute them.

sentences.sentence_tlingit: A kaadé áwé kandug̱éexʼch, «Yá du kaḵʼanáax̱áni, du kanéex̱ʼi yis.át áwé yáaxʼ,» tle tléixʼ tle yóo.
sentences.sentence_english: They contribute money for it, “[This is for] the fence around her grave; this here is for her headstone,” [they all work] together.

sentences.sentence_tlingit: Áyá yeedát tlél yéi at utí, ḵushtuyáx̱ tle ḵóoxʼ [chʼa aadóo sá wáa sá wuneeyí]. Á áyá ḵaa een óosh aadé yee.aadí áwé, Tʼaaḵú yíde, tle yan shuwutaaní áwé, tle ax̱ x̱ʼéidáx̱ kakg̱ishaxéet.
sentences.sentence_english: But now things are not like that; it doesn’t matter to people if something happens to someone. So if you would only go with us to the Taku River, after [the trip], you could take down my story in writing.

lines.line_tlingit: Áyá yeedát tlél yéi at utí,

sentences.sentence_tlingit: Tléil ax̱ tuwáa ushgú yá ax̱ yátxʼi g̱eig̱í— a x̱oo.aa de keijín jinkaat táakw ḵa keijínx̱ dax̱ sitee— tléil ax̱ tuwáa ushgú ḵut has awug̱éexʼi yá aadé ḵutoostéeyi yé.
sentences.sentence_english: I don’t want my poor children— some of them are 55 years old— I don’t want them to lose the way we used to live.

lines.line_english: I don’t want
my poor children—

sentences.sentence_english: So I too hope that you can take off a month and go with us if you have any chance.

sentences.sentence_english: Long ago at the time I was talking about, [before the time of] Naada.éiyaa, there were [two] giants at the mouth of the Taku River.

sentences.sentence_english: It’s right across from Keishixjixʼaa.

sentences.sentence_tlingit: Tle yóo shaa tle yóo yatee, tle yóo a yáx̱ yaawashiyi yé yáx̱ yatee, [Wasʼasʼéi yóo duwasáakw]. Á áwé wé Kax̱tóok náanax̱.á aa, áwé wooch káa ḵaa luyawdigúḵ, wé ḵudziteeyi át, tle has ḵuwdudlihaa.

sentences.sentence_english: Then [Wasʼasʼéi] decapitated [Lkoodaséitsʼk] there and threw his head over to the other side of the Taku River.
